#Text=US to sell precision-guided bombs to Saudi Arabia
#Text=Tuesday , January 15 , 2008
#Text=The Bush administration officially notified Congress Monday of its intention to sell sophisticated precision-guided bombs to Saudi Arabia .
#Text=The action , coinciding with President Bush ' s visit to Saudi Arabia , is part of a broader U.S. effort to bolster Gulf allies in the face of a more assertive Iran .
#Text=VOA 's David Gollust reports from the State Department .
#Text=The Bush administration has already briefed Congress on its arms sales plans for Saudi Arabia .
#Text=Monday 's announcement sets in motion a 30-day period in which the House and Senate can block the plan with a joint resolution - an action that appears highly unlikely .

#Text=Under the proposed deal , worth more than $ 120 million , the United States would provide Saudi Arabia with 900 kits and associated equipment to convert conventional gravity bombs into GPS-guided smart-bombs , known as JDAMs .

#Text=The weapons are a mainstay of the U.S. military arsenal and their accuracy would vastly enhance the capability of the Saudi Air Force , which has top-of-the-line U.S.-made fighter-bomber aircraft .

#Text=The sale is part of a broader $20-billion arms package for Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states announced by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Defense Secretary Robert Gates last August on a mission to the Gulf , aimed at shoring up U.S. allies concerned about Iranian influence in the region .

#Text=Several elements of the broader package including sales of Patriot anti-missile systems to Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates , and upgrades for Saudi Arabia 's AWACS airborne command and control planes , have already gotten congressional assent .
#Text=Officials here say they also expect the Saudi J-DAMS sale to proceed despite concerns expressed by some congressional supporters of Israel .

#Text=At the time the Gulf weapons sales package was announced last year , the Bush administration also committed to a 10-year , $30-billion arms package for Israel , representing a 25 per cent increase in annual U.S. arms aid to that country .

#Text=Briefing reporters , State Department Spokesman Sean McCormack said the administration has assured Congress it would do nothing to upset Israel 's military edge over potential enemies in the region .
#Text=" We 've spent a lot of time assuring that we abide by our commitments to a qualitative military edge for Israel , " said Sean McCormack .
#Text="

#Text=Under questioning here , Spokesman McCormack said the Saudi government has made  quantum leaps " in action against terrorist cells and financing in recent years and has begun the process of reform , though not necessarily at a pace that would please some critics .

column1: #Text=Two-thirds majorities of the members in both houses would be required to block the sale and officials here say chances for that appear nil .
